flags.title: User-Contributed Project
flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction:
As multi-instrumentalist musician and enthusiast, I always liked to look different musical instruments from those I already have. Regarding the Ukulele, since long ago I hear music and see videos about the instrument and different techniques of playing it. Recently, I've studied a lot about the activity of some luthiers, and this has motivated me to try to build a guitar or some other similar instrument, but the complexity involved mainly in manufacturing the body of the instrument, made me get to the Cigar Box Guitar. The next step was to explore the concepts of manufacturing Ukuleles and Banjos by adapting some of these concepts with some own ideas and material available.

Briefly, this project involves the construction of a Ukulele using a Tin Can as its body and making the neck from woods available at home. The goal is to use the less musical instrument parts possible, doing it all from zero.

The instrument isn't finished yet, but you can follow its development progress till the end.

lines.text: Measure and cut the wood piece for the neck leaving a few milimeters beyond the needed, what will allow you to sanding the wood piece till the shape of the neck. I'm using a piece of wood made of three layers bonded

lines.text: Cut the end of the neck 15 degrees and glue the peghead under the neck. I screwed the two pieces to keep it firmly attached
